text: Location: Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant,  Ukraine (USSR at time of incident)
What Happened: Explosion and fire in RBMK reactor 4 that led to a significant release of radioactive material.
Evacuation of ~50,000 people from the town of Pripyat.
The explosion resulted in the death of two workers. Twenty-eight firemen and emergency clean up workers died of radiation sickness and cardiac arrest within three months of the incident.
During a low-power test on April 26, 1986, the safety measures for operating reactor 4 were ignored.
The Uranium fuel in the reactor overheated and melted through the protective barriers.
This resulted in an explosion that demolished the reactor building.
The lack of containment structure allowed radioactive materials such as iodine, strontium, and
to be released into the atmosphere.
- Ignored safety measures and proceeded with an unsafe test.
- Allowed unsafe practices and did not ensure safety protocols were maintained.
– The lack of a containment structure around RBMK reactors compounded the negative consequences of this event.
Design flaws in RBMK reactors were addressed.
Nuclear plants around the world placed greater awareness on safety protocols.
Regulatory oversight for nuclear power plant design increased.
The International Atomic Energy Association provided direct assistance to improve nuclear safety in Europe and the former Soviet Union.
If you’re operating an RBMK reactor, it would be best to enhance the shutdown mechanisms for the system.
Adhere to safety procedures to limit the opportunity for human error.
Increase awareness of what can go wrong with nuclear power plants.
Emphasize training on how to properly handle emergency situations.
